Went to Chapters and got my hands on the hardcover collection of the Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark trilogy, with all the original artwork too! 
Funny thing, as much as I loved spooky things and horror, I never actually read these books when I was a kid. I remember them being so damn popular though - the kids in my school were always taking them out of the library. For me though, while the stories seemed creepy and scary, it was the illustrations that truly disturbed me. The covers alone made me nope out, so I never read them. And while the illustrations still do creep me the fuck out, I have a mad respect for the unique art style and how the illustrations make the stories all the more scary. The original artwork is DEFINITELY the reason why these were so popular back then.

The movie, by the way, was quite good. The acting was decent, the scares were great. I thought it would be a perfect little "gateway" horror movie for any kids wanting to get into horror. There were two scenes in particular that really creeped me the fuck out. Crossing my fingers they'll make a sequel!

Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark was released last week in the U.S. to positive reviews, and is based on the children's book series of the same name, about a group of teens face their fears in order to save their lives. If you're looking for a literary frightfest, check out the following horror movies, which I'll bet you didn't know were based on books.

I Know What You Did Last Summer (1997)

The novel, by Lois Duncan and first published in 1973, tells the same basic story. Four teenagers are involved in a hit and run and kill a man. Thatâ€™s pretty much where the similarities end. In the book, instead of a fisherman, the teens strike and kill a biker. The major difference, though, is the movie is basically a slasher flick and the book is most definitely not. In the movie, the four teens are haunted by the fisherman, who did not die in the accident, and who stalks and attacks them with his hook for a hand.

The Shining (1980)

In the novel, Jack is haunted by the ghosts within the hotel he and his family are caretaking for the winter, high in the remote mountains of Colorado, while in the movie, the demons that Jack fights are internal as well as external. Instead of the ghosts driving him insane, as in the book, the film version is already insane and the hauntings push him over the edge. The book helped solidify Stephen King as the premiere horror novelist of his generation and is now on the Mt. Rushmore of scary storytellers partially because of this book.

If you're looking for a literary frightfest, check out the following horror movies, which I'll bet you didn't know were based on books.

Psycho (1960)

The movie Psycho is mostly faithful to the book, though a lot of the details of Norman Bates, the troubled killer in both, are changed. In the book, he is immediately scummier and more obviously scary than in the movie. In the novel, Bates is also a slovenly drunk who immediately makes readers wary of him, whereas in the movie, he is presented as somewhat clean cut and normal before being revealed as the killer. This changes the nature of the terror in the book. It works very effectively, scaring readers with his potential and allowing imaginations to run wild, as a book should do.

The Exorcist (1973)
